Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The Web of Innovation: Using Website Data to Understand How Firms Innovate

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Firms are viewed as the central drivers of commercializing new technologies through value capture in the marketplace. How firms approach this process of innovation is relatively diverse and can be thought of as a function of several factors, including technology specialization and know-how, market receptivity, desire and ability to course-correct on strategic and tactical considerations, and access to alliances and networks. This research investigates the utility of website data to examine the innovative behaviors of high-tech, small firms in three substantive domains: nanotechnology, synthetic biology, and sustainable energy. Using small firms as the unit of analysis allows for higher order inferences to be made at the level of the industry, technology regime, and broader innovation system. This research provides a better understand of how knowledge turns into valued products and services that support national economic growth and results in a more complete understanding of the innovation ecosystem and appropriate add another much-needed data source and set of methods to the toolkits of social science researchers trying to understand technological progress.

This project harvests, analyzes, and reports on website data and evaluates its utility as a data source for understanding the innovation process. This work structures key variables from firm websites and operationalizes them as determinants and descriptors of firm innovation behavior. This research builds on an exploratory framework to apply computer science methods to the study of innovation, and as a result, crosses two disciplinary tracts that usually do not intersect with one another in great depth. As such, the project employs clustering and classification algorithms to operationalize key variables, thereby quantifying each firm?s market and technology orientation based on its online representation. Selected outcomes are validated against several data sources including enterprise databases, targeted interviews, and extant firm surveys.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER project studies firm innovation behavior using website presence, patenting activity, and other traceable online data. There are three main objectives of this research, the first of which is to produce an automated method of defining a sample frame (with website URLs) of small firms from a list of patent assignees. A second, related objective is pedagogical: We disseminate the method in a workshop-style format with hands-on labs that students can follow in a completely virtualized environment. Third, we further our understanding of the online behavior of small, high-technology firms. We theorize about the nature of website change over time and how narratives may unfold within groups of small high-tech firms (e.g., by industry).

The overarching methodological goal is to facilitate the use and analysis of “big data” sources in innovation studies. We focus on small firms in three main sectors: synthetic biology, nanotechnology, and renewable energy. The project harvests, analyzes, and reports on website data, capturing text to operationalize key innovation-related variables; to do this, the project employs existing web scraping software, NoSQL databases, cloud architecture, text analytics methods (e.g., named entity recognition and topic modeling), and regular expression matching. Clustering, classification, and finite Markov chain models are then used for analytical purposes to answer questions about how small firms communicate about their research and development, products and services, history, leadership team, etc.  

From a sampling and data collection standpoint, our method (a) captures employment data from different online sources, (b) uses supervised machine learning techniques to identify firm website URLs and specific web pages of interest, and (c) assesses bias in the final sample. The results show that out of 1,492 U.S.-based patent assignees in the sample, 1,390 have employment data, with 770 identified as having fewer than 500 employees. In total, we collected website data on 79% of patenting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in our sample, with smaller firms less likely to be represented with website data than larger firms, on average. 

In terms of web page classification, we were able to identify ‘about us’ pages with a final accuracy rate of 87% on the out-of-sample test set. (We achieved this accuracy rate using a single hidden-layer neural network model.) This improves on accuracy rates produced by prior research, which showed classification accuracy rates of approximately 80% using an alternative type of model (i.e., a support vector machine). Identifying certain pages of interest is important because websites are messy sources of data, not initially developed with the purpose of statistical analysis in mind. In this research, we isolate ‘about us’ pages to develop an experimental method of identifying topical change over time. 

Broader impacts of this work stem from the release of code and associated multi­industry datasets of small firm website data and derivative analytical information. We encourage science and innovation policy researchers to use these resources to answer additional research questions beyond the scope of this study. With some modest modification, new data collections should also be possible with the code. See https://github.com/euphonic/EAGER.

Additionally, we document the method in a workshop-style format with hands-on labs that students can follow in a self-contained, virtualized environment. This learning environment standardizes all system dependencies to ensure an accessible, immersive learning experience. Getting started with the workshop technology is possible through a short orientation guide with minimal configuration steps. The workshop itself covers six topics using a small segment of the sampled firms to:

  1. Identify firm URLs using low-cost search engine APIs
  2. Capture firm employment size from publicly available websites indexed in search engines
  3. Run a web scraping process that can scale to thousands of firm website domains when using cloud services
  4. Prepare sample frame and website data to optimize on data quality using machine learning and other programmatic approaches
  5. Generate topics from the corpus of website data, by industry
  6. Experiment with the construct of small firm narratives by analyzing topical change over time, paragraph by paragraph, using continuous Markov panel modeling

The primary outputs associated with this research are (a) one manuscript documenting the method and its results; (b) another manuscript examining the effect of website topical change on growth outcomes; (c) two conference abstracts and presentations; (d) the aforementioned workshop and its delivery to students and research professionals in the U.S. and U.K.; and (e) code and data publicly available on GitHub. The project website is available at https://www.dextr.us/nsf-eager.
